title: Fullicon Multiple Pill Cutter, Adjustable Pill Cutter for Small Pills with Accurate Pill Alignment, Stainless Steel Cutting Blade & Blade Guard, Pill Splitter with Free Brush & Pill Box (Grey)
features: 【Cut Multiple Pills at Once】Simplifying your pill preparation with the pill splitter for small pills, making it easy to cut multiple pills at once & quickly prepare your daily doses in just one step

【Accurate Cut】Silicone strips on the sides & base secure the pill in an accurate position. Place your pills into the pill cutter splitter ensures worry-free cutting experience with no slipping, or risk of inaccurate cuts or breakage
【Size Adjustable Design】Handling pills up to 0.6 inches in width, the pill splitter cutter cut pills in half, eliminating the frustration of pills not fitting into the cutter

【Sharp but Safe】Ensuring safety & precision, the sharp stainless cutting blade in the small pill cutter is securely covered, preventing any injuries during preparation & ensuring precise dosing. Besides keeping you safe, it also ensures the safety of your family. No need to worry about kids accidentally getting hurt when you're not watching
【Free Brush & Box】Including a brush for easy cleaning & a pill case for convenient storage, making the pill cutter splitter for small and tiny pills perfect for on-the-go pill management
description: Product Description Previous page Next page 1 Cut Multiple Pills 2 Accurate Cut 3 Size Adjustable Design 4 Extra Brush & Box What is the use of pill cutter? Using a pill splitter can help you get accurate doses when you're splitting pills. Can I cut my pill in half? As a general rule, if the tablet has a score mark or groove down the middle, it can be split in half. Be sure to talk to your pharmacist before breaking your pills in half. How can I split pills safely? Our pill splitter has a blade guard to provide a safe cutting environment. When the pill cutter is not in use, the sharp blade is able to hide automatically in the covered shield, effectively avoiding finger injuries.
